My Dear Alice,
I arrived here on the 19th inst. about 5 p.m. Concho time and here we are "waiting for the wagon" that we "may all take a ride" and thusly hango a tale that might be greatly [[chaww] out. Elongated or lengthened had I the time to do the subject justice.
Three days in nearby unclear was occupied, as I have already informed you in making the journey from Concho to "Grierson's Spring". When we arrived on the evening of the 10th and altho we drove about and tarried by the way side, two of the unclear which Captain Constable, or the L.M. Dept from (wished)

- wished for my escort wagons - so nearly played out that I decided that it was vest to exchange them for two of Capt. Keye's pack mules. The front axle fo the escort wagon was badly sprung and I came near leaving the escort wagon at the spring and taking one of Keye's Wagons instead - but as he had use for his wagon I concluded to rick going on with my outfit as it was. I loaded all my forage unclear of the unclear articles in the spring wagons in which I rode to lighten the load for the other wagons - I wrote you a note from China Fords. When Capt Keyes and this escort. and myself and mine parted company on the morning of thirteenth. I passed through Castle Bap about unclear that

day and reached Horse Head crossing fo the Rocks at 4 P.M. that evening where we encamped for the night it was my intention to take a small mounted escort from the Spring of "D" Company, but Keye's Company were nearly all out scouting  and he could not well furnish me any more, as he had to have an escort ready for Cherman's train. I had around 15 men for this duty, but reduced it to eight, so as to leave sufficient men at the Spring for Camp Guard. So I was obliged to stop and come on this, with Sherman's train or face the music up the bloody unclear and on to the Guadalupe Mountains, with the four men I had with me when I left Concho. Six

six men in all, including the drivers, leaving myself. So I took the chance and moved on. I thought that possibly I would meet unclear as he had been ordered out from Stockton with a detachment of twenty men. I have fresh tack at Castle Gap, which must have been made by his Command but did not see any of his detachment from the unclear of Castle Gap. I concluded that unclear had either struck a party of Indians and had a fight or had jumped a hard of unclear of unclear and had killed a number of them as fresh blood was to be seen upon the ground in a number of the places in considerable quantities. But as I saw

neither man, wild "injun," nor beast -- wild or tame. The matter had to be left in doubt. We moved onward and upward on our winding way on the 14th & without meeting any one or with any incident which I now remember worthy of accounting. We encamped that night at the Niagara Falls of the bloody Pecos, commonly called Pecos Falls, distance marched about 40 miles. The falls were not much to brag of, but were I unclear the only interesting feature of that section of the Country. The moonlight view of the falls was somewhat darkened by the immense clouds of Mosquitos which floated or flew about rather permiscuously *

20 miles up the Delaware Creek. In the morning we tightened up the ropes, chains and straps, lubricated the joints and cargo and set the old chariot in motion again. By the aid of the extra lead unclear we were by making use of piket ropes able to put Powell's teams on in front of Page's - making an 8 mule team and by hard work come loose and unclear unclear unclear we succeeded in getting on as far as the other stage unclear at Sulphur Spring making a distance of 20 miles that day. We moved on with our outfit or caravan about 8 O'clock on the morning of the 19th and altho' the road was hilly and rough and bad at places we got along quite well for about 10 miles. When passing over a place where the road was a little sideling? down went the Old Institution again with a crash, throwing out some of the occupants and some articles which went to make up the load. This time it was the right hind wheel which gave way and upon looking back this time I saw the wheel lying flat under the wagon, broken

to pieces - with the spokes scattered about upon the ground. I congratulated myself upon being within eight miles of Sibo's Camp and that we could unclear down unclear [[unclear[[ that objective unclear in the course of time even on foot. The men now thought it was no use to attempt to fix this old go-cart, but knowing that if I separated out little party it would occupy at least another day to get to the mountains. I again set the men to work to unload and right the old thing up on boxes and concluded there was but one way to fix or repair damages so as to go on all together and that was by making use of the broken wheel which had rolled off the wagon

so beautifully and brought us to a stand still on the 17th. We had already tried every way we could think of to get the spindle out of the wheel but could not succeed in making it fast so as to get the nutt off. Necessity however is the mother of invention and what we could not do before became easy when it must be done. I had the men get a large picket pin and with some to hold the wheel the pin was placed upon the broken spindle and it was driven so tight in the wheel that with a wrench the nutt was taken off and the wheel made available. I then had the left hind wheel taken off and placed on the right side of the wagon in place of the one which had been broken up and put the front wheel from which we had taken the spindle on as the left hind wheel.

Thus fixed up we moved on to Sibo's Camp, stopping to water at Independence Spring. From high points on the road I could see Sibo's Camp 12 to fifteen miles distant with my field glass. As we drew near to Camp we could see the officers and men moving about, evidently looking upon our outfit with wonder, trying to make out what or who was coming. They were much surprised when on a closer view to see that I was missing that make up as machine and upon examination Capt. Sibo and Lieut. Read? of the 25th Ward concluded that we did well to get through and that I ought to have the old go-cart pattented?. It was well I did not send in for a wagon when we first broke down as both of Sibo's

teams were in the way to Davis after rations - I thought of taking pack mules & going on from here, but concluded to wait the arrival of Shannon's train & then to take from it one good six mule team & wagon & proceed on our journey - I expect Shannon in to-day and will send the remains of the old chariot back to Concho - with his train - and then make my way to unclear via El Paso to Quitman. Making use of a Six mule train & wagon instead of the escort wagon. We can still make the trip by November 1st if I can get away by the 25th inst. On the 20th I & Capt Sibo with small detachment explored the country thoroughly in the unclear - of this and the place where

Lowell was encamped and Yesterday and the day before. We made a thorough exploration of the Blue River or Black River Canon of which I will write something more hereafter.
Having no officer with me from Wild China Ponds to this point - being alone as it were so to speak - I had ample time to commune with myself and like the unclear - Rady Pasod?  I kept up a great thinking - reviewing the past and speculating or conjecturing as to the future - During the entire time I was far from well and at times quite sick - but I had my mind fixed upon one subject and that was - to get better and recover my health if possible. The morning of the dreary unclear - rouste? along the Pecos was broken by occasional glimpses of the Mountain ranges to

south and south-west. First the hills about Stockton and Mountain peaks below to-wards Peno Blanca came in view as I passed from Castle Gap to-wards the Pecos and on the 14th the tops of the Mountain to-wards Davis and about Barilla Spring came in sight. Soon after as we would pass over higher ground the 12-mile Mountain so called nearer to Davis could be seen, and before night the top of Gomes Peak. 7. Oct. 24. 1878
Dear A-
As Shannon did not put in an appearance with his train last evening, I am obliged to still continue to "wait for the wagons." 
I spent last evening at Lebo's tents - playing Whist & other games. The Dr. & I played against Capt. Lebo & Lieut. Read & came out victorious. The weather here is mild & delightful. Cool at nights but warm & pleasant during the day. Capt. Lebo's Camp is situated on quite high ground at the base of the Mountains - and the location is rather airy at times for comfort. We have had one decidedly windy day since my arrival. When a more sheltered place would have been more agreeable. I am in hopes that Shannons trains will be in to-day so that we start on our journey to-morrow.

as we have a long tramp still before us.
I intend to take a ride 'round the point of the Mountains to the West to-day - to explore a little in that direction. Yesterday I explored Pine Cañon - which is in the immediate vicinity of the Camp. This is only about 5 miles in length & does not compare Blue or Black River Cañons. It is where the Spring entirely dry Except that about a mile & a half up, there is a tank of tain water in the locks called the "Bear's Bath Tub."
The Surveying Party - which passed thro' Concho  - about the 1st of Sept - Enroute to this section of the Country - is now here. Encamped just below the line between Texas & New Mexico near Mouth of the Delaware Creek.

to Guadalupe Peak. They have been here about a week - and are going to start South-ward towards Davis - to which point the have to go - in order to obtain supplies & draw rations & forage for the detachment of fifty - which accompany the Party from Fort McKavett.
At 8.O.clock A.M. on the 21st just myself, Capt. Lebo Lieut Read & Dr Ward - with each a Mounted unclear & a detachment of two men -(Cavalry) as Escort started to explore Blue or Black River Cañon. Our route took us by an old Indian trail along the base of the Mountains to the Eastward & over the foot hills, so called but which would be called Mountains at Concho. From the high point on our route we could a long distance to the Southward Gomes Peak near Fort Davis being plainly visible

The Smoke Mountains could be seen by turning our faces toward the south-west - fully fifty miles off - to the East we could see beyond the Pecos and on the North the Guadalupe range altho' two miles or more off seemed within pistol shot - in the bright sunlight - with the Mountain peaks towering upward from three to four thousand feet high. The scene was constantly changing like clouds floating in the sky. Yet always beautiful - look where you would. I've passed a number of fine springs between Camp and the Mouth of the Canyon and at Volunteer Creek passed a large herd of sheep which were being herded by Mexicans. When we saw them they seemed or looked small white rocks on the side of Mountain - but they were moving Eastward & not unclear down hill.

We concluded & saw that they were sheep. The herders had killed three Panthers a few days before. [Hence the hides off and pinned down on the ground to dry. The Doctor tried to purchase one of the skins - but could not succeed in making himself understood by the Mexicans. We arrived at the Mouth of the Cañon about 11. O.clock A.M. & proceeded up about 4 miles - Where we haulted & let the detachment go into Camp - and after resting about an hour - eating lunch - etc. We, with each an orderly - continued up the Cañon Mounted about 3 miles further beyond which it was not practicable to take horses.  When we left three of the men with the horses and taking one man with us - proceeded

on foot three to four miles farther and to a point beyond which we do not think any white men or even Indians ever penetrated these heavens. We were stopped by an impassable barrier of smothe perpendicular rocks on both sides - 500 feet high -- and directly in front - 40 to 5o feet & over which we had no means to make our way.
To attempt to give a perfect description of the Gorgious and Magnificent scenery of this valley and Cañon would be supremely ridiculous in me and would be a vain presumption & impossible task for one of the most accomplished gifted & talent persons in the world. The Mouth of the Canyon is not over hald a mile wide & is mostly taken up by the bed of the Creek or River.

composed mostly of white lime stone. Loose rock - gravel & large boulders - are scattered about here & there. The Mountains rise on either side - almost perpendicularly fully 3000 feet& from the base upward about half that distance. There is a thick growth of velvety looking vegetation Made up of pines, cedars, & inumerable varieties of bushes  - thick clustering vines minerals etc. etc. The balance or uper half is perpendicular cliffs of White line stone. Colored in places by mineral substances, black & yellow in places near the top of the cliff. Stalactites & Stalagmites glistening in the sunlight like polished silver can be seen from the valley below. The general direction of Canyon is East & West & Extends into the Mountains fully 10 miles - heading not far from Guadalupe Peak. Pine Spring & Capt.

Lebo's present Camp. After going into the Cañon about a mile from the Mouth, it bends 'round a high Mountain to the left & then widens out into a beautiful valley - filled with trees. Clustered together in almost every conceivable fashion. Embracing Pines of several varieties. Cedars, Hemlock & Juniper. White oak, Black oak, Maple, Ash, Birch, Elm, Wild Cherry & Manzanita. innumerable shrubs & a great variety of rustic grasses, Masses wild flowers etc etc. I never beheld such and endless variety in one place during my life before this spectacle burst upon my view in all its gorgeous splendor. The foliage was the most beautiful I ever beheld. The frosts have evidently set in with sufficient force to change the leaves of all trees except the Pines & Cedars. etc. & bestowed the colors of the rainbow conceivable tint

and hue. such the eyesight look where you would. The maple & Mansanita trees (the latter with its bright green leaves & beautiful little red apples growing from the valley below - up the mountain sides interspersed with Pines & Cedars. The Mountain cliffs & peaks & then the blue sky above all - made up a picture never to be forgotten by any man who ever beheld it - beautiful grand & sublime. It seemed as if we had suddenly become possessed of Aladdin's Lamp. The transformation was gorgeous & complete. It must not be forgotten too that the river runs thro' this valley with its beautiful clean pure water - forming as it rushes over falls - pools - & cascades - adding at every turn - its remarkable beauty to the varied scene. After

about six miles of this kind of scenery - the valley gradually becoming narrower. The Mountains because still more perpendicular. The sky above gradually diminishes in Extent. The unclear - sun? is shut and only touching the highest parts of the mountain cliffs. The air being chilly - the pools of water became more  frequent & are deep & still as death. Gradually the Mountain has closed and looking directly upward you see the blue sky looking like a ship of unclear lifted blue ribbons. Suddenly we are brought to a halt & is thought that we can go no Farther for in front of us is 20 feet of abrupt smooth rock. We hunt about and get a small fallen pine tree - and by placing it against the rock up we climb one after the other & unclear a short distance & then hold.

again looking for some way to overcome the obstacle. Soon we commence crawling on all fours one after the other under an immense mass of fallen rock & soon we got beyond it & push on. Now clinging to the rock along the narrow stream and sometimes grasping & clutching on to the trees & bushes now & then to be forced upon a section of the rock walls. Soon a deep pool is directly in front & there is apparently no way to get over or around without jumping down & swimming. Soon we think of some small fallen &  broken down Pines behind us & they are brought up. Thrown accross - as a bridge & one by one we walk over balancing as we go & altho a Misstep would have plunged us into water 10 to 20 feet deep. We all take the venture & cross safely. My Dear Alice
Your letter of the 24th Mch I received upon arrival here yesterday and that of the 26th to-day & possibly I may get another letter from you to-morrow before leaving Stockton.

I ordered an Infantry Escort for the trains - from the Post and have left cavalry detachments at Grierson's Spring & Stockton. Capt Keyes left the Spring yesterday with Companies "D" & "E" 10th Cavalry and Capt Lebo left Davis same day with Co "C" 10th Cavalry and to-day Capt unclear Kennedy? left Fort Stockton with Companies "J" & "L" and we expect to start to-morrow. The 4 companies, train, escort etc will come to gether at Pecos Falls from 40 to 30 miles north of this post and Co. K (Lebo's) will join the Column at Pope's Crossing of the Pecos. We have been very busy - since leaving Concho but - everything for the unclear

of the troops has so far been carried out in a satisfactory manner. We will have a little telegraphing to do in the morning - and there we will cut loose & soon be beyond communication with either Dept HdQr, or friends at Concho or elsewhere for sometime - possibly one month or more. So do not be alarmed if you do not hear from me for that length of time. I will unclear & communicate with you soonn if possible and think I may be able to do so by t he middle of April and you may rest assured that I will not fail to do so

every opportunity. I hope to accomplish all that may be required of my Command & take good care of it and myself. Expect to discharge my duty faithfully & well. & to the satisfaction of myself and others & return with all in good condition in due time & place things in proper shape for the Summer 's work - before going back to Concho. We have not as yet had time to call on the officers

and Ladies of the Garrison as I have, but expect to do so this evening.
Dr Smith dined at the post yesterday & to-day - but I have accepted any invitations to dine and refused Col Blunts kind offer of Quarter at the post. We moved into Camp and had our tents put up at once. I have been very comfortable. Altho' the weather has been almost too hot for comfort.

I may also send back some unclear to you at Davis from Pope's Crossing. of the unclear which will probably reach that post by the 12th to 15th of April. May also write you then. My Dear Alice,
This has been a very windy dusty disagreeable day, and we have a poor camp and less grass than we have had of any camp since we left Concho. The wind and dust has been very harsh on the eyes? and everybody is sort of disgusted with this part of Texas. I hope that I will not have to travel over this Pecos route very often hereafter. It might be put up with if a person was only on the way home. We hope to reach Pope's Crossing to-morrow and probably Black River the next day where I expect to rest the command for a day or two and where we will have good

and much better Grazing than we had had on the Pecos.
The Camp is considerably scattered in order to give more room for grazing. We are about a mile from the river but near the road in order to avoid pulling thro' heavy sand. Our cook is working under great difficulties. & we expect to get a full share of dust sand in all we eat to-day.

I judge that there is about one letter a month carried by the mail which runs between Fort Davis & Fort Stanton New Mexico.
